# Bipolar Junction Transistor (BJT)

1- Analysis fixed Bias/ Base Bias Circuit.

a. The Collector - Emitter Loop

Collector current
$$I_{C} = \beta I_{B}$$

$$I_{C} = \beta_{DC} \left( \frac{V_{CC} - V_{BE}}{R_{B}} \right)$$

From Kirchhoff's voltage law:

$$V_{CE} = V_{CC} - I_C R_C$$

![](_page_6_Picture_12.jpeg)

- $I_c$ is dependent on beta $(B_{DC})$
- The disadvantage of this is that a variation in $B_{DC}$ causes $I_{C}$ and, as a result, $V_{CE}$ to change, thus changing the Q-point of the transistor
- This makes the base-bias circuit extremely beta-dependent and unpredictable
- Hence **base bias is usually used in switching circuits where the transistor is either in saturation or cut off** but is rarely used in linear circuits

### Emitter Bias/ Emitter Feedback Configuration:

> [Resource](https://eng.libretexts.org/Bookshelves/Electrical_Engineering/Electronics/Semiconductor_Devices_-_Theory_and_Application_(Fiore)/05%3A_BJT_Biasing/5.5%3A_Feedback_Biasing)

> When designing an amplifier with this circuit, we want $V_{CE} = \frac{1}{2} V_{CC}$. In such a circuit, we get the maximum operation from the amplifier

![](_page_10_Picture_2.jpeg)

- Adding a resistor (R<sub>F</sub>) to the emitter circuit stabilizes the bias circuit
- Idea is to help make base bias more predictable with negative feedback, which negates any attempted change in collector current with an opposing change in base voltage
- If the collector current tries to increase, the emitter voltage increases, causing an increase in base voltage because $V_B = V_F + V_{BF}$
- An increase in base voltage reduces the voltage across ( $R_B$ ), which reduces the base current and prevents the collector current from increasing
- While this is better for linear circuits than base bias, it is still dependent on ( $\beta_{DC}$ ) and is not as predictable as voltage-divider bias
- To calculate ( $I_E$ ), apply Kirchhoff’s Voltage Law (KVL) around the base circuit

{11}------------------------------------------------

a) The Base-Emitter Loop

![](_page_11_Figure_4.jpeg)

From Kirchhoff's voltage law:

$$+ \mathbf{V_{CC}} - \mathbf{I_E} \mathbf{R_E} - \mathbf{V_{BE}} - \mathbf{I_E} \mathbf{R_E} = \mathbf{0}$$

Since $$I_E = (\beta + 1)I_B$$ :

$$V_{CC} - I_B R_B - (\beta + 1)I_B R_E = 0$$

**Solving for I**<sub>R</sub>:

$$I_B = \frac{V_{CC} - V_{BE}}{R_P + (\beta + 1)R_F}$$

{12}------------------------------------------------

2- Analysis Emitter Bias/ Emitter Feedback Configuration: b. Corrector
Emitter Loop

![](_page_12_Figure_2.jpeg)

### From Kirchhoff's voltage law:

$$I_{E}R_{E} + V_{CE} + I_{C}R_{C} - V_{CC} = 0$$

### Since $I_E \cong I_C$ :

$$V_{CE} = V_{CC} - I_C(R_C + R_E)$$

### Also:

$$\begin{aligned} \mathbf{V_E} &= \mathbf{I_E} \mathbf{R_E} \\ \mathbf{V_C} &= \mathbf{V_{CE}} + \mathbf{V_E} = \mathbf{V_{CC}} - \mathbf{I_C} \mathbf{R_C} \\ \mathbf{V_B} &= \mathbf{V_{CC}} - \mathbf{I_R} \mathbf{R_B} = \mathbf{V_{BE}} + \mathbf{V_E} \end{aligned}$$

    $$= \frac{19.3 \text{ V}}{481 \text{ k}\Omega} = 40.1 \,\mu\text{A}$$

a. $$I_C = \beta I_B$$

= (50)(40.1 $\mu$ A)\
$\approx$ 2.01 mA

a. $$V_{CE} = V_{CC} - I_C(R_C + R_E)$$
    $$= 20 \text{ V} - (2.01 \text{ mA})(2 \text{ k}\Omega + 1 \text{ k}\Omega) = 20 \text{ V} - 6.03 \text{ V}$$

a. $$V_C = V_{CC} - I_C R_C$$

= 20 V - (2.01 mA)(2 k $\Omega$ ) = 20 V - 4.02 V\
= 15.98 V

a. $$V_E = V_C - V_{CE}$$

= 15.98 V - 13.97 V\
= 2.01 V

or $$V_E = I_E R_E \cong I_C R_E$$

= $(2.01 \text{ mA})(1 \text{ k}\Omega)$\
= $2.01 \text{ V}$

a. $$V_B = V_{BE} + V_E$$

= 0.7 V + 2.01 V\

### 3- Voltage Divider Configuration:

- Method of biasing a transistor for linear operation using a single source resistive voltage divider
- Most widely used biasing method
- Developed by a resistive voltage divider that consists of $R_1$ and
  $R_2$ .
- $V_{CC}$ is the dc collector supply voltage. Two current paths are
  between point A and ground: one through $R_2$ and the
- Voltage-divider bias circuits are designed so that the base current is much smaller than the current through R2, ensuring that the base–emitter junction does not significantly load the voltage divider

### 3- Voltage Divider Configuration:

- The voltage-divider circuit is very straightforward to analyze because the loading effect of the base current can be ignored
- A voltage divider in which the base current is small compared to the current in R2 is said to be a **stiff voltage divider** because the base voltage is relatively independent of variations in transistor parameters

## 3- Voltage Divider Configuration: Analysis

- In a voltage-divider circuit in which I_B is small compared to I_2, first calculate the base voltage using the unloaded voltage-divider rule

$$V_{\rm E} = V_{\rm B} - V_{\rm BE}$$

$$I_{\rm C} \cong I_{\rm E} = \frac{V_{\rm E}}{R_{\rm E}}$$

$$V_{\rm C} = V_{\rm CC} - I_{\rm C} R_{\rm C}$$

$$V_{\rm CE} = V_{\rm C} - V_{\rm E}$$

## Bipolar Junction Transistor (BJT)

### 3- Voltage Divider Configuration:

Determine $V_{\rm CE}$ and $I_{\rm C}$ in the stiff voltage-divider
biased transistor circuit of Figure 5–10 if $\beta_{\rm DC}=100$ .

![](_page_17_Figure_3.jpeg)

![](_page_17_Figure_4.jpeg)

Solution The base voltage is

$$V_{\rm B} \simeq \left(\frac{R_2}{R_1 + R_2}\right) V_{\rm CC} = \left(\frac{5.6 \,\mathrm{k}\Omega}{15.6 \,\mathrm{k}\Omega}\right) 10 \,\mathrm{V} = 3.59 \,\mathrm{V}$$

So,

$$V_{\rm E} = V_{\rm B} - V_{\rm BE} = 3.59 \text{ V} - 0.7 \text{ V} = 2.89 \text{ V}$$

and

$$I_{\rm E} = \frac{V_{\rm E}}{R_{\rm E}} = \frac{2.89 \text{ V}}{560 \Omega} = 5.16 \text{ mA}$$

Therefore,

$$I_{\rm C} \cong I_{\rm E} = 5.16 \,\mathrm{mA}$$

and

$$V_{\rm C} = V_{\rm CC} - I_{\rm C}R_{\rm C} = 10 \text{ V} - (5.16 \text{ mA})(1.0 \text{ k}\Omega) = 4.84 \text{ V}$$

$V_{\rm CE} = V_{\rm C} - V_{\rm E} = 4.84 \text{ V} - 2.89 \text{ V} = 1.95 \text{ V}$

#### Bias configurations (4)

#### Voltage divider Bias:

DC ANALYSIS 1: EXACT METHOD

Using Thevenin theorem, Thevenin equivalent resistance and voltage can
be computed.

![](_page_20_Picture_5.jpeg)

Figure DC component

Figure: Thevenin equivalent circuit

Figure : R<sub>th</sub> determination

$$V_{CE} = V_{CC} - I_C (R_C + R_E)$$

Figure: $V_{th}$ determination

Analysis: $$R_{th} = R_1 \parallel R_2$$

Substitute: $$I_E = (\beta + 1)I_B$$

$+V_{th} - I_{R}R_{th} - V_{RF} - I_{F}R_{F} = 0$

$$V_{\!\scriptscriptstyle E}$$

$$V_E = I_E R_E$$

$$V_C = V_{CE} + V_E$$

$$V_{R} = V_{RF} + V_{F}$$

$$V_{th} = V_2 = \left[\frac{R_2}{R_1 + R_2}\right] V_{CC}$$

$$I_B = \frac{V_{th} - V_{BE}}{R_{th} + (\beta + 1)R_E}$$

#### II. Voltage divider Bias: DC ANALYSIS 2: APPROXIMATE METHO

$I_E = \frac{V_E}{R_E}$ $I_{CO} \cong I_E$

ifference between the exact and approximate methods is the effect of

## Bipolar Junction Transistor ( BJT)

### Voltage Divider Configuration Examples:

![](_page_25_Figure_3.jpeg)

Eq. (33):

$$\beta R_E \ge 10R_2$$

$$60 \text{ k}\Omega \not\ge 220 \text{ k}\Omega \text{ (not satisfied)}$$

$$R_{\text{Th}} = R_1 || R_2 = 82 \text{ k}\Omega || 22 \text{ k}\Omega = 17.35 \text{ k}\Omega$$

$$E_{\text{Th}} = \frac{R_2 V_{CC}}{R_1 + R_2} = \frac{22 \text{ k}\Omega(18 \text{ V})}{82 \text{ k}\Omega + 22 \text{ k}\Omega} = 3.81 \text{ V}$$

$$I_B = \frac{E_{\text{Th}} - V_{BE}}{R_{\text{Th}} + (\beta + 1)R_E} = \frac{3.81 \text{ V} - 0.7 \text{ V}}{17.35 \text{ k}\Omega + (51)(1.2 \text{ k}\Omega)} = \frac{3.11 \text{ V}}{78.55 \text{ k}\Omega} = 39.6 \text{ }\mu$$

$$I_{C_Q} = \beta I_B = (50)(39.6 \text{ }\mu\text{A}) = 1.98 \text{ mA}$$

$$V_{CE_Q} = V_{CC} - I_C(R_C + R_E)$$

$$= 18 \text{ V} - (1.98 \text{ mA})(5.6 \text{ k}\Omega + 1.2 \text{ k}\Omega)$$

$$V_B = E_{\text{Th}} = 3.81 \text{ V}$$
$V_E = V_B - V_{BE} = 3.81 \text{ V} - 0.7 \text{ V} = 3.11 \text{ V}$
$I_{C_Q} \cong I_E = \frac{V_E}{R_E} = \frac{3.11 \text{ V}}{1.2 \text{ k}\Omega} = 2.59 \text{ mA}$
$V_{CE_Q} = V_{CC} - I_C(R_C + R_E)$
$= 18 \text{ V} - (2.59 \text{ mA})(5.6 \text{ k}\Omega + 1.2 \text{ k}\Omega)$
$= 3.88 \text{ V}$
